snippet: A report by The Washington Post, which included information from Edward J. Snowden, suggested that roughly nine out of 10 communications involved people who were not the direct targets of surveillance.
abstract: Obama administration officials say National Security Agency routinely filters out correspondence of Americans that has no intelligence value as it targets suspected terrorists globally; statement is response to new disclosures by the Washington Post suggesting that roughly 9 out of 10 agency-intercepted communications involve people who are not direct targets of surveillance.

byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER and MATT APUZZO

lead_paragraph: A report by The Washington Post, which included information from Edward J. Snowden, suggested that roughly nine out of 10 communications involved people who were not the direct targets of surveillance.

headline.main: Officials Defend N.S.A. After New Privacy Details Are Reported
headline.print_headline: Officials Defend N.S.A. After New Privacy Details

keywords.value: Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board
keywords.name: organizations
